Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Heap Selection
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=127853030; y=_0ZmmMX7QBlzus2zky0tQkRP1gN0PVoETeMMIcrB51L2nykdRxF4
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod

Hi Ian, all,

I've been thinking about speciation within NEAT in general and also 
Ian's idea of using a heap (BTW wikipedia has some good background info 
on heap structures if you don't have Knuth to hand).

Here's a line of thought I had today, I'm not sure if it holds any water 
+ apologies if I'm repeating anything that's already been said.

I recognise that NEAT's current technique of defining either a constant 
speciation threshold or min/max threshold for the number of species may 
not be optimal. At this point though I think we should distinguish 
between the two (that come to mind) benefits of NEAT's discrete species:

1) Each species represents a distinct point or area in the search space, 
and therefore speciation allows NEAT to search several areas of the 
search space simultaneously.
2) Mating between genomes within a species are more likely to generate 
good offspring - than mating with more distant genomes from other species.

I'm not sure if there exists hard evidence/research to back up these two 
points. I'm happy to assume that (1) is the case. (2) though is a bit 
more shaky. Actually one experiment I would like to do is track the 
quantity and quality of offspring and to graph this against their 
origin, e.g. mutation or crossover, and the genetic distance between 
parents. I wouldn't be /too/ surprised if it turned out that crossover 
didn't generate many good offspring and thus I don't feel comfortable 
assuming (2).

Ok now consider that the discrete speciation in NEAT does indeed perform 
(1) fairly well, and there isn't that much room for improvement. 
Therefore any new speciation technique should probably maintain the 
benefits of (1) whilst improving (2). Does a heap based continous 
speciation meet these criteria?

Certainly the heap maintains genomes over a number of areas of the 
search space, or at least over one wide area. It's not clear to me if 
the genomes would form clusters in the search space, as with discrete 
speciation, or whether perhaps they would describe a tree structure. 
Thus I can see that (1) seems intact, but (2)?

It seems to me that the heap structure is trying to maintain two things 
- a hierachy of fitness and a hierachy of genetic distance. The first is 
explicity coded into the heap, the second though I think can become 
broken when really fit genomes bubble up to the top of the heap and 
become h-parents of genomes that are genetically dissimilar. Thus when 
selecting mating pairs we may end up with two very different genomes 
(couldn't we?), when ideally we probably want to select mates within 
some genetic distance range. Actually in discrete speciation we might 
find that some species generate good offspring with a wider or narrower 
range than others.

I'm going to leave it there as I'm not really forming a clear train of 
though on this one right now :(

Cheers,

Colin
